statement.p: David is conducting market research on the cost of a cell phone data plan. David has determined that the average annual cost of a cell phone data plan is 961, and that the distribution of costs is normally distributed with a standard deviation of 65.
a. Find the probability that a single randomly selected consumer spends more than 879 on a cell phone data plan.
b. The cost of the middle 30 of cell phone data plans falls between (round to the nearest dollar):
c. The most expensive 4 of cell phone data plans cost at least how much annually?

solution.p: Define the normal distribution in Desmos: \displaystyle{N}=\text{normaldist}{\left({961},{65}\right)}.

b. For the middle 30 of the data, need the remaining 70 of the data split between the left and right tails of the distribution. So the lower bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.35} of the area to the left and the upper bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.35} of the area to the right, which means \displaystyle{0.65} to the left.
